awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Enforcement, Citizenship Status, and the Construction of Identity
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the effects of enforcement on various populations in smaller nation states in which a recent executive order intensified enforcement on the basis of demographic and citizenship status. The PIs leverage the increased visibility of enforcement agents and the increased reporting of profiling incidents to better understand the role played by enforcement institutions in the formation of group identity and inter-group relations in the country. Drawing on an original survey and survey experiment, the PIs examine how enforcement shapes the ways in which citizens and non-citizens identify their group attitudes and experiences with differential treatment. Findings will shed important light on the extent to which enforcement may exacerbate demographic group inequality, a question that has become increasingly urgent in recent years following widespread social protest against enforcement excesses in many countries. 
 
The project posits that enforcement is a key institution that shapes group identity formation and politicization, particularly in a context in smaller nation state in which enforcement forces have been deployed for out-group repression. In line with the policy feedback effects literature, the project investigates the extent to which interactions with law enforcement, a central agent of the state, serve as an important process of political socialization, teaching citizens about their rights and position in society. In the context of group fluidity in a smaller nation state, the PIs therefore hypothesize that experiencing enforcement will affect the likelihood that an out-group individual will identify as a member of the out-group, as well as to increase the degree to which their group identity is politicized. The research will draw on multiple measures of group identity to study how state coercion - during a period of heightened out-group enforcement - shapes experiences with differential treatment and strength of group consciousness along lines of both out-group and ancestry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

 

The study advances our understanding of several crucial questions about the intersection of race, immigration, and law enforcement in the Dominican Republic, a context where relatively few identify as Black, despite a large population of Haitian migrants and upwards of 80% of the population estimated to be of African descent. Leveraging a recent crackdown and expansion of police authorities in immigration enforcement, we conducted a survey examining the role of police and immigration enforcement in shaping racial identity formation and experiences with racial discrimination. Our survey employed multiple measures of race, as well as an oversample of dark-skinned individuals and residents with Haitian ancestry, yielding a higher proportion of Dominicans identifying as Black than has been found to date. Moreover, we find widespread experiences with and perception of discrimination shaped by both skin color and Haitian ancestry, and a relationship between these experiences and strength of group consciousness. By exploring how different approaches to categorization and experiences with discrimination shape the choice to self-identify as Black and the development of group consciousness among Black Dominicans and Haitian migrants, we provide important insights regarding the relationship between race, inequality and racialized state coercion. We are also able to assess the relationship between socioeconomic indicators and race and skin color, which has never been done for the Dominican Republic due to a lack of data.

 

 

 

Outcomes and Broader Impact

 

 

Guidance on Measurement of Racial Self-Identification for Census Officials 

 

By employing multiple measures of race – including self-reported and interviewer-reported skin color, open-ended, closed-ended, street race, and binary black-white questions – our findings demonstrate the variability of racial identity depending on the construct that is used, and point to pathways for allowing individuals to more accurately report their race. As the Dominican Republic only began employing a question about self-reported race in the national census of 2022, our findings can help inform officials within the National Statistics Office about potential revisions to future census or annual household survey questionnaires to capture the country’s racial diversity more accurately. The research team will prepare a policy brief for the National Statistics Office summarizing these findings.

 

Guidance for Government Officials on Policy Feedback Effects of Heightened Immigration Enforcement 

 

Our survey demonstrates widespread fear of being targeted for deportation by police and immigration agents, among Dominican citizens and Haitian migrants alike. Amid frequent reports of rampant reliance on racial profiling under the guise of enforcing immigration laws, our findings will help inform the Ministry of the Interior and Police about the policy feedback effects of this approach. Our survey also offers insights on other policy approaches to immigration that have public support and do not rely on racial profiling. The research team will prepare a policy brief for the members of a police reform commission and the National Ombudsman’s Office summarizing our findings.  

 

Guidance for Civil Society Advocates 

 

Our survey also yields important findings about public experiences with and perceptions of discrimination based on race and national origin, as well as the public’s support for the rights of Haitian immigrants and their Dominican-born descendants. These findings can help shape public education campaigns and advocacy strategies of civil society organizations. The research team has held two briefings with Dominican civil society organizations to present these findings and will prepare a report summarizing these results.
